Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Training Program in Sustainable Energy Recovery from the Earth -- Educational Innovation at the Intersection of Geosciences and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports the development of a new Ph.D. interdisciplinary training program at Cornell University focused on sustainable energy recovery from the earth. Students in engineering and in geosciences will be provided with a common language in interdisciplinary science and design that will accelerate technological progress in the sustainable exploitation of Earth's energy resources with acceptable environmental consequences.

There are complex intellectual challenges associated with the design of new subsurface technologies that extract energy from geothermal, conventional, and unconventional fossil resources, or safely sequester waste products like CO2. Trainees will participate in research that adds to fundamental understanding of transport processes for thermal energy, and of fluids and fractures in engineered rock systems. The initial interdisciplinary training will occur through a series of courses that introduce natural systems phenomena, energy conversion principles, economic, social and ethical considerations, and methods of industrial ecology (life cycle analysis), of systems design and simulation, and of risk analysis. Student teams will draw upon this coursework foundation for their analysis and design projects that deal with real world, field-based, cases. Trainees will develop skills to design energy options in consideration of environmental, economic, and social benefits and risks, and to communicate with those who must make informed decisions. In doing so, the nation gains a workforce able to utilize the Earth's energy resources in better balance with the natural environment.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2017, Cornell University completed a National Science Foundation-supported interdisciplinary graduate-level Training Program in Sustainable Energy Recovery from the Earth – Educational Innovation at the Intersection of Geosciences and Engineering. The Cornell Earth-Energy program trained, in a new way, doctoral and master’s students for a range of energy technology applications. Students in engineering and in geosciences were provided with a common language and a set of fundamental problem solving skills in interdisciplinary subsurface science and design. As their careers progress, they are well positioned to accelerate technological progress in the sustainable exploitation of Earth’s energy resources with acceptable economic and environmental outcomes.

There are complex intellectual challenges associated with the design of new subsurface technologies that extract energy from geothermal, conventional, and unconventional fossil resources, that can store energy produced by intermittent power sources, or that can safely sequester waste products like co-produced oil field water and carbon dioxide. The Earth Energy IGERT Trainees completed individual and team original research projects in order to discover and develop new technologies with which to utilize subsurface energy resources and materials at commercially relevant scales in an environmentally sustainable manner.

The research accomplished by the Trainees has added to fundamental understanding phenomena associated with transport and reaction processes for thermal energy utilization as well as the consequences that accompany extraction and utilization. Some of the Trainees characterized the occurrence and behavior of fluids moving through fractures in natural and engineered rock systems. Investigation of supercritical fluid mixtures led to new insight important to developing large scale energy storage devices. Concurrent with the years of this project, awareness grew of the risk of inducing earthquakes through manipulation of subsurface fluids, and the Earth Energy Trainees contributed to documenting the connections between fluid injection and earthquake generation. Trainees demonstrated the heterogeneity of unconventional reservoirs for natural gas, and investigated the connections between fracture behavior and that heterogeneity. Trainees evaluated the extent to which rocks of New York, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia are well suited for the extraction of geothermal energy in amounts sufficient to provide district heating for networks of residential, municipal, and commercial buildings as well as for low temperature industrial process heating.

The initial interdisciplinary training occurred through a series of courses that introduced natural systems phenomena, energy conversion principles, transport and chemical reaction in subsurface environments along with economic, social and ethical considerations, and methods of energy life cycle analysis, of systems design and simulation, and of risk analysis. Students drew upon this coursework foundation for their analysis and design projects that dealt with real world, field-based, cases. Annual field study modules were implemented to real-world energy production sites to allow students to utilize their course-based learning in multidisciplinary problem solving, to observe the interface between energy production and environmental resources like fresh water systems, and to interact with both energy industry professionals and the communities who host and must regulate the industrial sites.

Earth Energy Trainees developed skills to design and evaluate energy options in consideration of environmental, economic, and social benefits and risks. They learned to communicate with the general public, with technology specialists who are not from their own specialty, and with those who must make informed decisions. In doing so, the nation has gained a workforce able to utilize the Earth’s energy resources in better balance with the natural environment.

Twenty-two NSF-supported Trainees and four other doctoral students whose programs were like those of the trainees but funded by other sources have completed, or remain on course to complete soon, their doctoral degrees. Four additional Trainees chose to complete a Master’s degree and then move into the work force immediately. Over the course of the IGERT, more than 15 undergraduates were involved with IGERT-related research. Key elements of the educational and research programs developed under this NSF-sponsored program have been institutionalized by Cornell and are now a part of the College of Engineering’s graduate education program.
